data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Primissime idee
data.desc:
Very initial ideas following the delivery of the brief:
Ecologism taken to the extreme, engineering of nature, speciesism. Following the review, in which we were asked to start from a much broader research rather than immediately diving into possible scenarios.

Issues: the meaning of conflict and the meaning of ecology.

data.title: Definizioni
data.desc: General research on definitions of the theme. Individual deep dives into the topic of ecological conflict revealed that some themes overlapped, leading us to identify four macro-themes of ecological conflict. It is important to always ask: where is the conflict? Is the theme we are reflecting on truly ecological, or are we veering into other types of conflict (e.g., value-based)?

data.title: Artificiale = iperecologico
data.desc: The artificial as hyper-ecological, within a non-anthropocentric vision that places all living beings on the same level.

data.title: Conflitto genera conflitto
data.desc:
Human conflict as a generator of ecological conflicts.

We fear that this theme might be too predictable.

data.title: Conflitto tiene l'equilibrio
data.desc:
Ecosystem imbalance as a consequence of a total absence of conflict.
Alternatively: there is no ecology without conflict.

data.title: Parallelismo
data.desc: Parallelism between current conflicts and “natural” conflicts (e.g., predator-prey dynamics) to reflect on conflict as something feral and animalistic, yet natural.

data.title: Ulteriore ricerca
data.desc: Following the previous review, in which we were asked to be more specific about the themes and to focus on ecological issues that concern humans, we have outlined three themes.

data.title: Paradosso
data.desc:
Theme of the paradox.
• What if the artificial were considered more sustainable than the natural?
• What if the direction of biomimicry completely replaced nature?

data.title: artificiale / naturale
data.desc:
• If everything becomes manipulated or uncontrollable, what truly remains “natural”?
• How much of our “humanity” do we lose when we increasingly rely on technologies that, by imitating what was once natural, manage to control us?

data.title: Temporalità incompatibili
data.desc:
• What if time were a finite resource to be redistributed?
• And what if we had to negotiate our rhythms with those of ecosystems? What form would a society synchronized with the rhythms of the Earth take?

data.title: TRACCIA
data.desc:
- restituire intera ricerca svolta, anche se non state più portando avanti quella via. 

 - coerenti con la relazione parent e child, nodo generatore, nodo di sintesi, bisogna fare i nodi e collegamenti con cognizione di causa.

 - non usare nodi placeholder vuoti o non significativi con solo una desczione scarna, senza tag o area o titolo o simili, ogni nodo deve essere un minimo curato. 

•⁠  ⁠utilizzare sempre dove possibile l'utilizzo dei titoli.

•⁠  ⁠inserire sempre le "Areas" disciplinari del nodo.

•⁠  ⁠usare i "Tags" per indicare la "sotto-tipologia" del "type". 
Esempio: per "Source" si può usare il tag: case study, reference, article, artwork, dataset, book, website... etc  --> ci sono degli esempi in help (?) o per tutte le altre tipologie tra parentesi. e inoltre quel tutto il resto che ha senso taggare (non inserire o ripetere le aree)




*
⁠"Research" non è un'area, le aree sono i domini, le discipline esplorate.

•⁠  ⁠evitare: lista di ricerca--> unico nodo--> lista di proposte --> unico nodo feedback --> lista 
- fare: l'idea/proposta deve essere collegata alla sua idea generatrice (poi che inoltre siano collegati tutti anche a un nodo feedback come avete fatto va anche bene, ma non può escludere la sequenza concettuale generatrice delle proposte)

data.title: Review
data.desc:
The project has improved compared to the previous version.

Suggestions:
• Consider various anthropocentric perspectives (egocentrism, biocentrism, cultural centrism).
• Nature appears too passive: the narrative should instead subvert the established order, offering a different and more conflictual point of view.
• It is important to use the term “human being” instead of “man.”
• The conflict should not be limited to “human vs. nature,” but should also include “human vs. human,” showing more specific and segmented dynamics.

It is emphasized that ecological conflict is not necessarily violent, but rather brutal and devoid of empathy: nature is not “green” or harmonious, but a complex and competitive system.

data.title: Scenario 1 - Paradox
data.desc: Stilare scenario 1 - paradosso

data.title: Scenario 2 – Plant's sound
data.desc: Plants have evolved to communicate their stress through piercing cries. Walking on the lawn, drought, cutting the flowerbed, deforesting, weeding — all create agonizing screams. Instead of finding a way to prevent plants from suffering, humanity invents a device that allows you not to hear the pain.

data.title: Scenario 3 - Struggle against ourself
data.desc: AAAAAAA DA SCRIVERE

data.title: Research post-review
data.desc:
Greater research and more in-depth analysis are needed of situations in which nature does not merely endure the effects of human activity, but acts actively and interacts with the environment.

Ecosystems, species, and natural phenomena continuously respond to changes imposed by humans, altering biological cycles, local climates, and social dynamics. Studying these active interactions allows for a better understanding of ecological conflict.

data.title: Ecocentrism
data.desc: Ecocentrism is a worldview that places nature at the center, attributing intrinsic value to it and not just viewing it as a resource for humans. It opposes anthropocentrism, which sees humans as the focal point of everything, and promotes an approach based on respect, ecosystem conservation, and the pursuit of a harmonious balance between humanity and the environment.

data.title: Deforestation theme
data.desc: Deforestation represents the act by which humans take space and resources from the natural ecosystem, compromising the benefits they themselves receive. In a speculative scenario, this logic is reversed: humans become the object of exploitation or must restore the lost ecosystem services, paying the price for their own actions.

data.title: Water memory theme
data.desc: Humans use water primarily as a resource to exploit, but water is not actually a passive entity, as it can perceive information from the external environment, analyze it, and retain it in its “memory.”

data.title: Agroterrorism theme
data.desc: Agroterrorism: a form of subversive struggle targeting the agri-food sector through malicious or criminal acts. Agroterrorism can use pests or biological agents to damage production, the economy, and food security, threatening consumer trust and national well-being.

data.title: Sound theme
data.desc: Plants under stress — due to cutting, dehydration, or other conditions — emit ultrasounds similar to clicks or crackles, inaudible to humans but detectable with special microphones. A team from Tel Aviv University, in collaboration with Harvard, has shown that these “cries” propagate through the air, revealing a form of plant communication that has been little studied until now.

data.title: Scenario Hypothesis - Certification / Labeling Brand
data.desc:
Fictitious Name: EticaAlimentare – European Transparent Certification System
What it does:
Offers a new label guaranteeing “absence of contamination from bio-engineered organisms.”
Born in response to the collapse of local crops.
Becomes a tool both for cultural defense (“protection of traditions”) and aggressive marketing.

Why it is interesting:
It reaches the consumer during shopping.
Appears ethical and neutral, but is loaded with ideology, politics, and social pressure.
Divides the market: those with the label and those without.
Raises tension in the conflict without producing anything, simply by regulating the narrative around food.

data.title: Verification of Accuracy
data.desc: Verification of Accuracy Based on the Outline Provided via Email

data.title: Verification of Accuracy
data.desc: Verification of Accuracy Based on the Outline Provided via Email

data.title: Verification of Accuracy
data.desc: Verification of Accuracy Based on the Outline Provided via Email

data.title: Review
data.desc:
• It was discussed how to present the projects: start from the premises, then move to the core issue, and finally the “what if.”


Scenario 1
Paradox: works well but needs clearer communication, introducing the theme of standardization and clarifying the group’s role (a company producing artificial trees with a platform for “lymphatic credits”). The advisor asks, “And then?”, to encourage further narrative development.


Scenario 2 
Struggle Against Oneself: interesting but too complex; it should be simplified and made more plausible. The idea of a machine that measures pain could help highlight the ecological conflict.


Scenario 3
Agroterrorism: too many themes and overdeveloped “what ifs.” The concept of plants as weapons works but should be made more concrete, perhaps from the perspective of a seed-weapon manufacturer.

data.title: Presentation and Review
data.desc:
Morning → Presentation
Afternoon → Review (prof. Guida) + reading comments on presentation


Review:

Scenario 1 is promising but needs to be deepened and made more concrete, with a clear narrative that translates the three identified considerations, avoiding solutions that are too simple or literal.

For Scenario 2, Guida highlighted the need to better develop the conflict, making it narratively more engaging without falling into ideological positions. This scenario has more design challenges.

We will continue with Scenario 1.

data.title: Scenario 1 continuation
data.desc:
Scenario Redefinition:
artificial trees, initially designed to produce energy and improve air quality, become symbols of consumption and social status. Their purchase is tied to “lymphatic credit,” accumulated by cutting down natural trees, thus turning sustainability into a competitive market and incentivizing the destruction of natural ecosystems.


Identification of considerations:

1
Empathy with the conflict: the issue of ecosystem destruction, often perceived as distant, becomes a direct experience, highlighting individual human responsibility.

2
The tree as a living ecosystem: the tree is not just a plant organism but a habitat that supports many species; its removal has cascading effects on the environment.

3
Commodification and standardization: the tree becomes a consumer good with economic value and market cycles, losing its natural dimension and becoming an object comparable to any industrial product.

data.title: New research for new scenario
data.desc:
In-depth research on:

•Terminator Seeds: a type of genetically modified seed designed to produce sterile seeds, preventing their germination and thus use by farmers for subsequent crops.

•Seed Saving: the practice of collecting, preserving, and replanting seeds from existing plants to maintain crops, preserve biodiversity, and promote self-sufficiency and savings. It involves selecting healthy plants, harvesting mature seeds, drying them, and storing them in a cool, dark, and dry place.

data.title: New scenario (2)
data.desc:
Scenario:
the seed trade has become a lawless territory, completely deregulated, accessible, and free. There are natural, hybrid, and synthetic seeds: some promise exceptional yields, others eliminate pesticides, but there are also mutated seeds that do not germinate or spread diseases, and even seeds designed to kill. Anyone can legally purchase them, online or at physical distributors, freely choosing: nourishment, tool, or weapon?


Considerations:

1
Conflict Generators: nature, domesticated and reassembled, becomes a means of conflict, transformed into an arsenal that appears harmless but has disastrous consequences.
	
2
Human Intervention: by regulating nature, humans assume the power to decide what can or cannot exist, what is good and what is evil.

3
Not Naturally Good: “natural” is no longer a guarantee of authenticity: modified seeds challenge trust in nature as a safe refuge.

data.title: Second presentation
data.desc:
We presented the final scenario, that was already well defined. We presented the fifty models of small three as well, and the 3d renders. Values, Vission, Mission, Tone of voice were already defined and are the same for the two communication directions we presented.
The two directions differences are: logo, payoff, fonts, palette and photography. See screenshots attached.

We were given feedback about the interaction and branding. The interaction is good as it is. Branding (visual) must be revised: there are no good logos and photography is incoherent with values (we shouldn't show the greatness of nature if we intend to destroy it). For the next presentation we need two different branding directions.

data.title: Branding
data.desc:
We defined our interaction with the prototype: interchangable covers (cortex) that will trigger different responses (in therms of lights, data and smell). We are selecting woods based on their aesthetic, rarity, uses, smell.
Logos are still in the making, payoff almost defined, we started to produce the first mockups.
Branding is done.

data.title: Revisione
data.desc:
Branding is good. Payoff must be revised. The final naming is "treeal".
Interaction is good too, data can be shown on a web app maybe? Show dimensions of the prototype.
The sensation of paradox must be forced trough exaggerated data and visualization of the journey from a tree to an object.

data.title: Feedback
data.desc:
It's important to focus on what we want to communicate. Signaling what tree to kill doesn't work (legally speaking). How can we be coherent with the brand? Final project must not be an app. Maybe we should focus on the buying funnel.
We could make the metaphorical act of killing a tree phisical. The brand must be really convinced that what it is doing is good for the planet.

data.title: Exploring option 1
data.desc:
We are developing the first scenario. We must find a solution for the interaction.
Our product will be a tech tree and there will be a buying frenzy about it: paradox of overconsuming and greenwashing. Our idea is to make an app that lets user signal trees in order to kill them. User will gain credits that can be used to buy tech trees. It can be seen as a refurbished product program: bring us your old tree and we will give you a brand new one.

data.title: Developing option 1
data.desc: We want our trees/objects to be collectibles but also to be sold as health devices. There will be three sizes. Once the customer gets to the shop, he will be able to customize his three. In order to finalize the transaction, he will be requested to "prove" that he understant the need to cut old threes in order to make better ones. He will do so by using a remote that works like an axe and he will have to cut down a tree. How many trees will depend on what kind of customization he will choose.

data.title: Revisione
data.desc:
Conflict is not clear anymore. We should find a bad thing to do in order to make a good one (for the planet): make a list of unsustainable actions. Axe does not work. We should underline the paradox of doing bad things thinking we are doing something good.
What the interaction should do is making people realize that humas are not sustainable for the planet. We must exaggerate the data: data is extremely important. It's ok if the tree in the end will also be our interactive machine.

data.title: Making a step back.
data.desc:
We tried to take a step back and make a list of unsustainable actions we do in order to do something good for the planet. Es. The ocean cleanup.
We stopped thinking about the interaction because it is driving us away from our goal. We are thinking about being a ong/tech startup. That will need funding in order to plant tech trees instead of real ones: the funding will come from the small tech tree that will work as already seen.

data.title: Review
data.desc:
We should make some reasearch on other companies that need to collect their resources. The company must be coherent with the mission. The machine will need to be a touch point for customer and company: datas are absolutely fundamental. The tech tree must not be only a product: it needs to have a communication function. Show the tree. 
Decide if we want to be a company or a startup. Ong doesn't work for us because they are not designed to make profit. Start with branding, we will understand the interaction later.

data.title: What are we going to be?
data.desc: Startup vs company

data.title: Branding
data.desc:
On the 21, 24 and 28 /10 review we have progressed and finalized the branding part: values, mission, vision, golden circle, tone of voice, moodboards.
We have also come un with the final idea for the interaction: wood covers that will interact with the tree and also trigger data display.
Logos, palette, fonts and photography are still tbd, we are currently working on the first two. Naming is still tbd: treeal or cortex

data.title: Review
data.desc:
The first feedback we received was that the first visual identity proposal works better, though some aspects still need refinement.
The shape is not right, it should resemble a tree, but at the moment it looks more like a mushroom, partly because of the cover that makes it bulkier.

Some did not understand the purpose of the interactive machine: we focused too much on how the product works (within the scenario) and overlooked its role in communicating our values.
The paradox should be made explicit during the interaction.

data.title: Refining identity
data.desc: We chose the first identity option and we are refining it.

data.title: Refining interaction
data.desc:
Rethinking the tree’s shape: adding a screen to display the data and changing the ‘canopy’ so that it resembles a tree more closely.
We also rethought the data visualization and how users interact with it, which could be connected to data from real forest trees (through an app? Or a screen?)

data.title: Review
data.desc:
We shouldn’t present two different product families. The large tree is our only real product, while the small tree is the communication device connected to it and that support our storytelling. We only produce the large artificial trees, which aligns with our mission.

Treeal therefore becomes an energy-producing company, not just a product maker. Like an energy provider, it buys land to install artificial trees that generate energy.

We also reconsidered data visualization and the user experience: we need a digital journey showing what happens step by step. For example, when the user selects a tree, they can see it on a map and know where it comes from.

We defined different communication levels:

Level 0: the device shows the energy produced.

Level 1: the cover explains that a real tree was cut down (e.g., one oak equals 800 covers) and where it came from.

Level 2: the object at home reinforces our message — for example, making a sound when a real tree is cut down or intensifying purification as the selected forest is deforested.

In short: the company doesn’t sell a home product. The small tree is only a communication machine that talks about our single product: the large artificial trees.

data.title: Review
data.desc:
The idea of installing artificial trees because “everyone is doing a good deed” (like long-distance adoption) is too fragile. The communication cannot focus only on the household device—the powerful part of the narrative is the Treeal forests.

We need to return to our original scenario, focusing less on the product and its catalog, and more on what we actually do (create artificial forests) and communicate this clearly through videos, posters, and storytelling. We also need to understand our real audience: investors, governments, and institutions that fund ecological restoration. We offer an alternative to real trees, more efficient and impactful in fighting climate change.

The device should trigger a speculative reflection, but we must strengthen the communication: highlight the conflict, clarify Treeal’s rhetoric, and address people’s environmental sensitivity and desire to participate in a revolutionary change. Underline the paradox.

The cover works: more covers mean more forests cut down. The form doesn’t necessarily have to look like a tree. Posters should not just express the concept; they must show how Treeal communicates and what service it provides.

We also need to clarify the added value of the object (why not just an app?) and explain where the captured CO₂ goes.

data.title: Function and Connection
data.desc:
We further clarified every point of the scenario, especially how it works. Now the audience can support the cause by acquiring the small tree, which:

Performs the functions of the large tree (e.g., converting CO₂ into oxygen…), and

Acts like a ‘modem’, connecting users to the artificial forest. By choosing to participate, users can monitor the progress of the company and engage with the cause.”
After the revision, we tried to reconnect all the points and adjust the scenario to ensure coherence and alignment with what the interactive machine is meant to be.

data.title: Sketching the tree shape
data.desc: We began sketching possible forms for the big tree starting by choosing some references, both to visualize it and to get an idea of how to proceed with the development of the interactive machine.

data.title: Sketching the interaction machine
data.desc: We also started brainstorming different ideas for the communication device, realizing that it doesn’t need to look like a tree, but should focus on its communicative functions. Its operation would remain similar: the user inserts a piece of wood (from the different types available), and the device reveals data about the origin of that wood as well as the performance and efficiency of our artificial tree, derived from the same tree that provided the inserted piece of wood.

data.title: Refining identity
data.desc:
We have defined a direction for the visual identity:

Font choice: Serotiva

Images: Focused on the natural degradation of nature (not caused by humans)

Posters: Phrases that position us above nature in a slightly sharp and provocative way—the idea being that nature is outdated or surpassed.

data.title: Teaser trailer
data.desc: We researched references and inspirations to develop the project teaser.

data.title: First teaser idea
data.desc: The first teaser idea is to show the same tree with civilization developing around it, conveying that nature has remained unchanged and now needs to evolve.

data.title: Review
data.desc:
The small tree is the merchandise, while our activity is supported by governments.
The communication device is the way the company presents the product to the public—it doesn’t actually filter air or absorb co2. It’s purely for communication. 

It’s important to separate the device (showroom experience) from the product (what the user has at home), which remains fiction. The theme of consumerism should be part of the storytelling, but not through the product itself.

In the showroom, users test different types of wood and then choose one, with which the company “sells” the product -> configurator.

We also need to decide which data to show and how, so next time we can prepare interface sketches.
The posters work well: nature in decay with contrasting copy, combined with a very technical interface.

data.title: New interaction ideas
data.desc: After the review on November 11, we continued working on the interaction of the communication device. We wanted to find an interaction that could evoke the core values of our project. Among the ideas we explored, we developed one that involves “cutting” the wooden blocks away from the table on which they rest, making the paradox more explicit.

data.title: Review
data.desc:
We realized that the way we present and interact with the communication machine needs to be simplified. The idea of cutting the wooden models doesn’t work: it’s too complex, hard to design, and the limited number of models reduces its impact. A clearer direction is to use a small tree-shaped token that the user detaches and inserts into the device—an act that symbolically mirrors planting a real tree in the forest.

The experience must remain simple: one gesture that immediately triggers useful feedback. The machine should communicate the performance of the real tree in our forests, not the miniature one. We also need to improve how we visualize maps and data, and better define what happens before, during, and after the interaction.

Overall, the device should guide the user toward a meaningful, coherent action without unnecessary spectacle—simple operations with significant, thought-provoking feedback.

data.title: New communication device 3
data.desc:
In the end, we decided to completely change direction and focus on something fundamental yet invisible: performance. This is why we chose to develop a communication machine that allows users to actively discover the performance of our artificial trees—something that would otherwise remain hidden.

The user always has eight different types of wood to choose from, representing our Treeal forests, where those specific species are harvested. The idea is that the user selects one type of wood and inserts it into the communication machine, so that all the data displayed afterward refers to the chosen species. The performance metrics change depending on the wood type, because the data is shown through comparison—for example: “To absorb this amount of CO₂ you would normally need this many cedar trees, whereas one single Treeal achieves the same result.”

To do this, we have imagined two possible options:

data.title: First option
data.desc: The first option is to use a monitor with augmented reality to frame our small tree. In this scenario, the miniature tree is no longer a product but purely a communication tool. It doesn’t perform any function on its own—its sole purpose is to convey our values.

data.title: Second option
data.desc: The second option involves a device that resembles a portable electronic microscope—or, more generally, a handheld monitor. By placing this device onto specific areas of the communication machine (its “hotspots” or touchpoints), the user can reveal data about the tree’s performance: CO₂-to-oxygen conversion, temperature, electricity production, and so on. The idea is that the user must actively search for the information, just like a scientist, rather than receiving data passively on a screen.

data.title: Review
data.desc:
The current grid layout is unclear, and the centering points for the circles are missing.

Posters need shorter, more direct copy, for example: “Nature fails. Treeal doesn’t.” They feel more suited for indoor use. The focus should be on the “cut” and one key data point, using images of unhealthy or moldy trees. The grid can be reduced or removed, and zoomed-in details added.

The website layout works, but line spacing could be tighter, headings bolder, and text hierarchy clearer. The color palette should be reconsidered, particularly the use of orange.

Teasers should be under 20 seconds, narrative-driven, and clearly communicate the project’s promise. Stock footage is too detached, and pacing should be faster. The main video should highlight the performance of the forests first, revealing the small tree only at the end. Martina’s teaser proposal works well, slowly revealing degraded nature before delivering the claim: it’s time to move forward.

The communication machine works up to pairing with the wood pieces. 3D mapping is tricky, but placing a device on hotspots to explore data is promising. Roots reveal root data, canopy shows leaf data, making the interaction active and engaging. Device design should be refined for clarity.

Finally, the home kit needs clarification. Users should understand that buying a tree allows additional chips to be purchased. The viewing device could be included in the kit alongside instructions for the web app. The lens could be part of the tree, and the app should have a clear interface, possibly with NFC interaction

data.title: Second teaser idea
data.desc: The second teaser concept is to show nature gradually failing on its own. As this happens, our graphic signs begin to appear one by one, until we finally reveal close-up details of our Treeal tree lighting up.

data.title: Third teaser idea
data.desc: The third teaser concept is a directorial experiment that involves a group of people gathered around a tree. After hearing an off-screen signal hinting at the presence of a “better” tree—ours—they slowly decide to leave the first tree and move toward the Treeal.

data.title: Review
data.desc:
The storytelling needs to be stronger. Previously, the interaction was simple but conceptually powerful. Now, by introducing multiple devices and scenarios, we risk losing the focus on the company’s core values: performance, green, technology, and transparency. These values need to be clearly reflected in the machine and its interaction.

The wood token should be raw, unprocessed wood—something rare, almost only like a museum fossil. This becomes a clear touchpoint for the audience, linking the value of sustainability to the interaction.

Currently, the modem—the object sent to the user—is not fully justified. Its role needs to celebrate the performance of the artificial tree while marking the “end” of nature. The concept could be that users receive a piece of the tree as a memorial, highlighting both the inefficiency of real nature and the superiority of the Treeal. The object should convey critical reflection, not just interactivity. 
The content—what the data communicates—is more important than the medium. The goal is to show comparative data that makes the user reflect immediately: for example, how much CO₂, PM10, or energy a single Treeal can manage versus dozens of real trees.


The storytelling should make users reflect on the contrast between natural and artificial performance, while the machine communicates these facts clearly in a short, engaging interaction—ideally within 10 seconds

data.title: Review
data.desc: During the review, we were advised to refine several aspects: both the communication—especially the use of our graphic sign—and the communication machine itself. We now need to clearly define the user experience, as well as the form of the device and the machine.

data.title: Refining identity
data.desc: Consolidation of the distinctive graphic element in our visual communication: an orange circle that highlights the negative aspects of nature.

data.title: Refining identity
data.desc: We created a visual identity guidelines manual to ensure consistency across all communication artifacts.

data.title: Technical components
data.desc: We began outlining the technical components of the communication machine to understand how it can be built and which parts we will need.

data.title: Review
data.desc:
For the website, we need to simplify the layout, emphasize the real lens effect using the circle, and include a dedicated subscription page with a clear call to action.

For the posters, we should adjust the padding of the content boxes, make the data inside them clearer, highlight the elements within the circles more effectively, add direct calls to action, and brighten the imagery since the photos are currently too dark.

Regarding the teaser, the sound should be simplified: instead of a rising beat that gets cut off, we should use a soft, steady pulse that fades gently, with less pronounced rhythm. The text should be placed at the center rather than in the bottom left corner.

On the technical side, the lens will use an RFID tag while the readers are placed inside the tree, allowing us to remove the magnet. Adding distance sensors will enhance immersion—data can blur and sharpen depending on proximity, and both the tree and the lens can pulse with light to indicate alignment. Each touchpoint must trigger a clear response.

For data visualization, we should use a framing element and make better use of the circle to fill space and communicate the contrast between “having the tree” and “not having it.”

The large tree should be redesigned to resemble the current small model rather than appearing too round.

data.title: Shaping the communication device
data.desc: We clarified the form of the communication machine and defined the overall user experience, supported by a storyboard that maps out each step of the interaction.

data.title: Review
data.desc: In this revision, small corrections were suggested in view of the December 2 presentation.

data.title: Presentation
data.desc: We presented the development of the project. Once the scenario was consolidated, we refined the communication and visual identity through various applications such as posters, billboards, and the website. We also defined the experience and appearance of the communication machine, and we presented the project teaser.

data.title: Teaser
data.desc: The final version of the teaser.

data.title: Communication machine updates
data.desc:
Hardware & Electronics:
- Procurement and bench-testing of components for the Arduino architecture: LED rings, Hall sensors, RFID system, circular display, and cabling.
- Compatibility verification and preliminary circuit assembly.

3D Printing:
- Analysis of printing parameters and file preparation (slicing) for the production of the tree's physical parts.

data.title: Communication machine updates
data.desc:
Replacement component for the circular display and integration of the bill of materials with auxiliary components (dedicated LED power supply, extended cabling). 
Acquisition of consumables (filament) to start additive manufacturing.

data.title: Communication machine
data.desc:
Communication Consolidation: made detailed refinements to communication assets and data visualization. 
The strategy and visual identity are now fully consolidated, validated and definitive.

data.title: Teaser updates
data.desc: We refined the sound design for clearer audio and reworked the animation curves to correct movement fluidity, eliminating previous jerkiness/stuttering

data.title: Review
data.desc:
Fine-tuning on existing communication assets. 
In parallel, we are integrating strategic feedback to define and develop the structural components of the communication ecosystem yet to be implemented.

data.title: Communication machine updates- connecting arduino
data.desc: Connecting the first cables to the Arduino (in particular the LEDs), routing them through the 3D-printed parts.

data.title: Review
data.desc: Short review on comunication machine updates and data visualization animation

data.title: Presentation
data.desc:
For this presentation, we bring:
– a defined concept and identity
– communication materials: finalized posters and various applications, with the exception of the website
– the communicative machine: fully functional from a technical standpoint, but still to be completed from an aesthetic point of view

data.title: Review post presentation
data.desc:
The presentation went well, but it could be slightly improved.

The communicative machine is fine, but the lens animations and the overall interaction need to be enhanced, as they currently feel a bit mechanical.

data.title: Data visualization updates
data.desc: Storyboard for the future data animation (esempi in allegato)

data.title: Communication machine updates
data.desc: We continue 3D printing the parts needed for assembly.

data.title: Communication machine updates
data.desc: We install the first sensors and cables.

data.title: Communication machina updates
data.desc:
Starting from the leaves at the top, we assemble the tree and progressively install the LEDs and Hall sensors, connecting the appropriate cables and routing them through the designated channels.

Finally, we install the RFID reader located in the trunk and connect it to Arduino and TouchDesigner.

The LEDs are also connected to a dedicated power supply to ensure proper current flow.

We also connect the lens to the PC via an HDMI cable.

Everything works.

data.title: Communication updates - poster
data.desc: Various printouts and minor corrections to the posters.

data.title: Communication machine updates
data.desc: Cutting a small wooden cube, which will be inserted into the dedicated housing where an identification sticker for the RFID sensor is attached.

data.title: Christmas break
data.desc:
We’ll take a few days’ break before enhancing the project.
Next steps will be:
– Strengthening the physical prototype: improving the 3D model, cables, and interaction
– Integrating sensors with the eight types of wood
– Developing the digital ecosystem: aligning the physical experience with the online experience

data.title: Teaser update
data.desc: Some videos have been regenerated and replaced, and several texts have been refined and improved.

data.title: Communication update - Data visualization
data.desc: Data animation (using after effects)

data.title: Project Advancement Status
data.desc:
Quick temporary update about the advancement of the project, will catch up later with more precise descriptions.

In the last month we:
- finalized the 3d printed tree (printing, sanding, refinement, painting, glueing, installation)
- finalized the Arduino and touch designer part (electrical components and code)
-designed and built the custom "table" for the tree model from scratch
- tested and perfected the interaction
- produced the 48 animations needed for the interaction
- carved the wood blocks
- filmed the longer video (ideas, script, actors, equipment, locations, shots, post production)
- programmed the whole site and the "unit" personal page
- produced the box for the "unit" as a phisical artefact (box, content of the box, wood block with tag, map and system overview/instructions)
- generated all the images needed for the project
- produced the requested 32 pages document about the project
